content: pages 4 and 5 for more details row 3 chain 1 in 3rd loop single_crochet across turn 72 see pictures 1-6 on pages 4 and 5 for more details row 4-18 repeat row 2 & 3 alternating end on a row 2 you can make it wider by doing more repeats row 19 chain 2 in 3rd loop half_double_crochet across 72 fasten_off and weave in ends pattern variation for a slightly different look you can use half_double_crochet throughout instead of alternating single_crochet and half_double_crochet row 1 work 72 fhdc 72 or as many as it takes to make it the length you would like your cowl turn after blocking i like my cowl to be 35 inches long which means before blocking it s usually around 30 moogly blog has a tutorial for fhdc here if you would prefer not to do fhdc you can chain 74 half_double_crochet in the 3rd chain from the hook and every other chain 72 row 2 chain 2 in 3rd loop half_double_crochet across turn 72 see pictures 1-6 on pages 4 and 5 for more details row 3 chain 2 in flo half_double_crochet across turn 72 see pictures 1-4 on page 4 for more details row 4-15 repeat row 2 & 3 alternating end on a row 3 you can make it wider by doing more repeats row 16 chain 2 in 3rd loop single_crochet across 72 fasten_off and weave in ends the picture to the right is an example of this variation page 3 pictures of front loops and 3rd loops 1 2 back loops front loops front loops 3rd loops 3rd loops 3 4 side view top view front loops front loops 3rd loops 3rd loops pictures 1 - 4 show the front loops and the 3rd loops that are used throughout this pattern page 4 5 6 front loop 3rd loop of final stitch in the row third loop of final stitch in the row pictures 5 - 6 show the 3rd loop of the final stitch in the row be careful when you get to the end of the row when you re working into the 3rd loops the front & back loops have by this time have been pushed to the front of the fabric so that i don t miss this stitch and so that i don t have to count i put a stitch marker in the 3rd loop when i make my first half_double_crochet in the row prior finishing once you are done crocheting i highly recommend blocking your cowl i soak mine in lukewarm water with a bit of wool wash i use kookaburra wash - no scent added or eucalan for at least 30 minutes then squeeze it out and lay flat to dry completely when i lay mine out i make sure it is the length and width that i want it to be blocking cleans the cowl you would be surprised at how dirty the yarn can be and really softens it
